The eight year old told me that he didn't know where their mother was and their father didn't give it bleep
So that woke me up and I did some research and I discovered that while LA is one of the wealthiest the most glamorous cities in the world we have one of the highest poverty rates in the country we have a forty five thousand gang members
We have more foster children and the homeless children than anywhere else in the United states
And we also have more incarcerated youth than anywhere else in the world twenty thousand kids are locked up every year in Los Angeles
So uh I'm also a screenwriter and I felt compelled to make a difference and so I uh after much a struggle I was able to finally teach a screen writing workshop to thirty teenage boys who were incarcerated for all kinds of serious crimes
And at the end of my program most of his kids learn how to read and write others wanted to go back to school and apply to college and one tough gang leader even had a tattoo removed from his neck in his hand
So based on that success I launched the second screen writing workshops this time at a coed detention center and I got the same results
So I met another writer and I shared my experiences and she caught me the next week to tell me that her professor Leslie statements that the American Film Institute was going to give me five thousand dollars to start a nonprofit organization and that was Twenty years ago and we have served thirty seven thousand you since then
So what did you feel like to go back and it uses a sense of accomplishment or do you get assumes through so much more
I think the latter I guess there's a sense of accomplishment and we've had some amazing success stories
But when I see the need not only in Los Angeles but throughout the country every city has this issue of
Fifty percent of our inner city youth are dropping out of school a these are our future system sees it this is our world that we live in and we need to educate and give these kids motivation and hope
On the arts have unfortunately been cut from most budgets
Are as being considered unnecessary and yet research has proven that not only do the arts and encourage you to stay in school and improve their academic test results
But they also alleviate tension and a bill self confidence and steam and for the trouble of children that create now serves as really essential and science has proven that arts on increased the brain neurons and do all kinds of amazing
Things such as uh we discovered that if it's a young child can learn how to keep the steady beat through music
It's Scientifically Proven that it accelerates they're reading
And when the um language skills so we're using these techniques to educate our children and to motivate them to become positive productive citizen
Has the learning about create now described as giving use in need opportunities to find their voices to arts mentoring in education walk us through give us an example paint a picture of what one of these ... or ... events ... how does that work
What we operate in three ways the first wave volunteer driven so uh it's almost like a dating service where Los Angeles county is one of them is the largest county in the country and it's very broad so we're able to not falling tears in their own neighborhoods with kids they're in trouble
So we have a network of about a hundred agencies such as emergency shelters foster group homes rehab facility and schools and we are able to refer volunteers to the agency said they want to work with
Somebody may want to work with little children Newark domestic violence victims others may want to work with teen moms
We get them training on how to work with these children we get them all the materials and equipment that they need and then we also help them to develop their curriculum and then we come and ate all of our programs with workshops for the children were they get parties and get bags with lasting souvenirs
So some volunteers may say look I'm really busy I can only volunteer once a week for a month
We set that up others may say I want to do this long term we set that up
The second way that we operate is through schools on most many schools and uh are not getting any arts education so we are able to to provide them with a longer term programs that were able to measure and show the impact of the work that we're doing
And then the third way that we operate is in community based project where we might get funding to a larger project to an art art festival or a mural program in a in a park or in a community center
So those are the three ways that we operate and they're they're all kinds of stories in ways that I can tell you how that works but it really has an impact on that very lasting and widespread
Will tell us about the impact anecdotally one have you seen someone who comes through this at risk youth who participates in the program how do you see new lives changed
Well one of my favorite examples is tacit Caulfield toss it grew up in a very poor neighborhood with an abusive family she started running away from home between the ages of twelve and Fifteen and she was nine different detention facilities during that time
She took a TV writing workshop that one of our volunteers taught um this woman had written on the shows for a married with children and fresh print for ballet aren't she wanted to get back
To us it took her class she bonded with a mentor and I also mentor and gave her additional resources such as the computer and I and others are support
... was able to receive a scholarship from Warner Brothers she graduated from USC film school she actually took her first year of law school in Chicago
She performs stand up comedy all around the country she produced and directed a feature documentary on how comedians to break into stand up she's working on her second documentary on teaching abused children how to use their tragedy to form comedy she's published three books written a number of threats and she got her real estate license
So this was a young woman who was headed for a lifetime of being incarcerated or worse and now she's an incredible a community citizen who's giving back
How is the program received by schools by communities by individuals do they knew about it do they respond you have a track record the ease so strong that it's pretty well no no
Well yes we're getting requests from all over our reputation has spread we've received a national media attention and international wars for work
But there's so much lead and not enough money to provide all of the port that's needed um but we we do what we can where we're working with LA you at the end and charter schools and other schools to provide programs for their students on a volunteers hear about it through their friends and through the Internet
Um and I'm an agency that says shelters and I'm detention facilities rehab centers are begging for for programs
So we do what we can but we're a small grassroots kind of organization but this year we're really going to where we're growing tremendously in terms of
Resources and support and in terms and each time we grow we were able to reach more children so we basically doubled our revenue every year for the last few years and we've doubled our outreach an ex financially so
Last year we reached twenty five hundred kids and our goal is to reach on a you know for ... a four thousand kids and a and more each year to grow more and more
You know do you create now and we're talking with Joe ... Joe what is the motivation for you is is that you see how willing words in your you see how many are not yet
[noise] yes that's a large part of it on I don't have children of my own so I feel that all of the children and our world are my children and I think that if everybody gave back and help children than we would have a much better world because these children are our future
And while many people may disregard them because they don't identify with them where they come from a different background
Um these are the kids that are going to be your
Your neighbors and your fans that hopefully and and and do good for our world [noise]
So if we don't help them now that we're going to be paying dearly through our taxes and social welfare to keep them in prison in jail for instance
Um there there are thousands of foster children there is an estimated half million foster children in our country when they age out when they turn Eighteen they're left to fend for themselves and an average foster child has Fifteen to twenty placements before they turn Eighteen
So here's a child who has no family no support no life skills or social skills they're going to turn Eighteen and be kicked out to fend for themselves
And sixty percent that these kids within one year will become homeless incarcerated or dead
So unless we do something to intervene and to give them life skills and job training and support mentoring is the real key then we're going to be paying for it with our taxes to incarcerate them so as an example I'm an average and a child who was incarcerated in Los Angeles
We have to pay two hundred and thirty thousand a year to keep that child incarcerated now that money went towards prevention programs such as creating what create now is doing we prevent them from ever going to jail and they would go into college instead
